text: have you ever come away from a
conversation wondering what the other
person thought of you maybe you worried
that you said something silly or stupid
or that they were just laughing at your
jokes to be polite do they even like me
you wonder well they want to see me
again well you're not alone we've all
been there we always think the worst and
come up with all these reasons that
people might not like us but research
says that we shouldn't you see for over
a decade researchers have been studying
the difference between how we think
other people perceive Us and how they
actually do this is known as the liking
Gap in one study two participants met in
a lab the experimentor left the room and
the subject sat next to each other and
had a 5-minute conversation a computer
on the table secretly recorded them
after 5 minutes the experiment returned
and the participants went to separate
rooms to fill out a survey they rated
how much they liked their conversation
partner and how much they thought their
partner liked them using a seven-point
scale the researchers found that the
subjects significantly underestimated
how much their conversation partner
liked them the study combined all the
participants ratings into an actual
liking score and a perceived liking
score on average the subjects thought
that their conversation Partners would
have rated them at a
5.17 out of seven but they actually gave
them a much higher average score of 5.82
people's self- ratings were far too low
another study tracked new college dorm
mates having conversations as they got
to know each other over several months
again the researchers found out that
still the students underestimated how
much their friends liked them after each
interaction this shows that the liking
Gap isn't just a one-time thing that
only happens in quick interactions with
strangers it's a persistent feature of
our everyday social interactions you
might think that the liking Gap is
basically harmless an interesting
psychological finding with little impact
on our lives however this couldn't be
further from the truth the liking Gap
can lead us to socialize less and miss
out on opportunities to connect with
others which ultimately affects our
happiness success and overall
fulfillment it can harm our self-esteem
and prevent us from expressing ourselves
authentically and if you're struggling
with these feelings and finding it
overwhelming seeking support can make a
significant difference that's where
better help comes in who are the
sponsors of today's video better help
offers professional counseling services
that can help you navigate these
challenges boost your confidence and
improve your social interactions leading
to a more fulfilling life with better
help being entirely online you can
message your therapist at any time and
schedule live sessions when it's
convenient for you and if your therapist
isn't the right fit for any reason you
can switch to a new therapist at no
additional charge with better help you
get the same professionalism and quality
you'd expect from in-office therapy but
with a therapist who is custom picked
for you with more scheduling flexibility
and at a more affordable price
betterhelp has a special offer today
where you'll get 10% off your first
month just go to betterhelp.com
simproved pill thanks again to
betterhelp for sponsoring this
video so why does this happen why are we
programmed this way well psychologists
think that the main reason is that we're
too self-critical we pay far more
attention to the negative things about
ourselves than other people do in
another study participants had a
conversation and afterwards they wrote
down what they thought the other person
was probably thinking about them it
found that everyone that thought the
person they spoke to was thinking
thoughts far more negative than they
actually were as we all do people
focused on the things that they thought
they did badly in the conversation and
could have done better and this stopped
them from realizing how much their
conversation Partners liked them now
while it can be good to notice where we
may have slipped up so that we can
improve next time we shouldn't let it
influence our beliefs and how much
others like us we're Our Own Worst
critics another reason for the liking
Gap is that in most casual conversations
we don't get feedback on how we're
coming across unlike at work where we
often can't avoid getting feedback
unfortunately people we meet in our
personal lives almost never come out and
say things like I like you or I enjoy
talking you even when they do not
getting feedback means we have to rely
on our own beliefs about a conversation
which are generally overly negative
because of our internal doubts and
insecurities finally as you've probably
noticed during social interactions
there's always lots going on in our
brains and loads to keep track of we
have to listen to what other people say
come up with things to say back think
about our body language and a million
other things all this can be tough to
deal with and makes it hard to pay
attention to the small signals people
give us that they're enjoying the
conversation like nods and eye contact
missing out on these cues again means we
don't realize how much others like us so
how can we reduce the liking Gap number
one most importantly we can get out of
our own heads and shift our attention
trying to focus on the people you talk
to more than usual asking them questions
and really listening to their answers
keeping your attention fixed on other
people will help you focus Less on
yourself and all the things you think
you're doing wrong number two practice
self-compassion and treat yourself with
the same kindness and understanding you
treat your friends with remember you
might think that you're the one always
saying the wrong thing and making a fool
of yourself and that everyone else is so
likable but we all think the same to
everyone else you're just another
likable person who's much more
interesting and social than they think
number three if you're really Brave you
can ask friends colleagues and family
members you trust for honest feedback on
how you're coming across this gives you
a more accurate and objective idea idea
of how you interact with other people
which can counteract your internal
doubts and overly negative
self-perceptions also don't be afraid to
ask people if they'd like you to clarify
something you think they might have
misunderstood so that there's no room
for misunderstandings and so that you
don't come away from the conversation
wondering whether someone took something
the wrong way remember the liking Gap is
incredibly common by understanding it
and doing things to reduce it you can
improve your social confidence and build
stronger connections with others which
are the foundation of a happy and
healthy life so the next time you come
away from a conversation worrying and
doubting yourself remember that
according to science the other person
probably liked you much more than you
think I hope you found this helpful and
I'll see you in the next video
